Let’s be real: CS2 is an absolute disaster. If you think otherwise, you need to dive back into legacy CSGO to understand how a real game feels.
The fundamentals of CS2 are laughably worse; CSGO runs smoother, feels better, and offers movement that isn’t a clunky mess. You don’t have to take my word for it - most pro players have openly admitted that CSGO is superior in virtually every aspect except for graphics. The optimization in CSGO is the result of years of meticulous polishing, while CS2 feels like a half-baked joke that can’t afford to take its time. If it doesn’t improve at lightning speed, it’s destined to wither away and die.

People are rapidly losing faith in this entire project. It’s a sinking ship, and Valve seems completely oblivious to the chaos around them. Meanwhile, out-of-touch investors continue to throw money at Valve, clinging to the belief that the company will deliver the "next big thing" - whether it’s an operation, a major update, or something else entirely. This speculation might eventually bear fruit, but for now, it’s the only thing driving the recent spike in skin prices - not any real improvements in gameplay or the anti-cheat system. And don’t even get me started on the absurd slogan “what you see is what you get.” It’s a total farce, especially with the whole subtick system mess. The gameplay constantly feels like it’s off by a few milliseconds, making it frustrating and inconsistent. Valve seems more interested in chasing shiny new distractions like Deadlock, which will never match the success of either CSGO or CS2. Player numbers for that game are already dropping, and let’s be honest - the initial surge was just the excitement of a new Valve release. The gameplay is dull, the graphics are mediocre at best, and frankly, it’s just boring.

Valve completely dropped the ball with CS2. They should have delayed this train wreck by a couple of years. Imagine if they had launched this version as a beta today instead of pretending it’s a finished product; it wouldn’t be nearly as disappointing. And for the love of God, the anti-cheat system is an absolute nightmare. It’s so poorly implemented that it raises serious doubts about whether Valve even cares about fairness in the game. If they don’t wake up and address these glaring issues, they risk losing the dedicated player base that has stuck around through thick and thin. It’s infuriating to watch my beloved franchise decay and wither away due to Valve’s incompetence and laziness. They rake in billions upon billions and can’t afford to expand the development team working on CS2?

I had a very long break from CS (and gaming in general), so I was pretty excited to get back and enjoy the gameplay. That happened to be impossible as in at least 20% of your games you'll match up against someone cheating.
Back in 2014-2017 you would also occasionally meet someone cheating, but usually on higher ranks such as LE, LEM, SMFC, GE, that's why (I think) they cheated in the first place — to get to higher ranks and stay there.

Downloading CS years later (and having 0 skill left) I was surprised to find out that now you have silvers and novas flooded with cheaters, which makes 0 sense to me — What is those guys' goal? Why are they ranked so low using cheats? So, in 2025 cheating is not something you occasionally find among high-ranks competing between each other, but rather an issue you simply cannot avoid. Among other things, this makes the game very unfriendly for newbies who expect to play against someone in their skill bracket.

Someone might say "you are just bad and that's why you think others cheat" and while I get this POV, it is simply not the case. I might not be good anymore but I certainly remember the game's physics and stuff like that. It's quite easy to detect a cheater when you played the game for the first time in 2003. (Also, a 0 level, 1 year old, 50 hours in game Steam account having 80% HS% is simply something very, very suspicious).

Also someone might say "just don't play on Valve's servers, go to FACEIT". Firstly, I just want to casully play the game for an hour to relax, not to be all 'competitive' and ruin other's desire to win. Secondly, why can't the game be playable "out of the box" with no need to have any kind of 'add-ons'?

Update 1/21/25:
- Unskilled players are now using DMA (Direct Memory Access) PCI Cards to cheat
- Combined with a second PC - a DMA card slotted in PC A sends realtime memory to PC B which can then be read/analyzed/acted upon
- PC B can simply read the memory on PC A, and can send realtime undetectable ESP onto PC A when combined with a display fuser
- DMA Card when also combined with a M&K Controller ("KMBox"), PC B can send realtime inputs (Aimbot, Triggerbot, etc) to PC A
- DMA Card can be repeatedly flashed with new firmware making detection near impossible
- There is an entire black market for undetectable firmware
- Valve doing nothing about these DMA Cards on top of not even issuing a statement shows they simply do not care about the "elite competitive experience"
- Valve will take action against legitimate players finding a loophole in the Armory Pass, and in a few hours - but will not take any concrete action against players abusing the entire game (hacking) and for years

- VAC is the worst anti-cheat in existence. Valve takes HWID of users however, they will not ban based on HWID. They only ban by account so the hacker can just make a new one and do it all over again.
- Valve is making a huge profit off NOT banning hackers. When a hacker gets their account banned, they just get another one and purchase prime ($15). Valve clearly sees this as a revenue source and will never actually take any real action against cheaters.
- There is a secondary market for leveling fresh accounts to premiere and selling them, people use inexpensive hacks to level accounts and then re-sell them for more
- People are running automated AI-based bots that can dupe weapons and automatically cheat same as in TF2
- Premiere game mode is completely off balance. Once you reach 10k+ ELO your matches will only net you ~50-100 ELO and you will lose between ~300-1000 every game. Complete timesink.
- Valve's "subtick" is garbage. The game will always have peeker's advantage - if you have a high ping around around 50ms-100ms you will always have that much more time to see someone on your screen before they will see you
- Public "find a group" feature is filled with Russians posing as "professional" players who invite you to lobbies, try to get you into a discord channel and then socially engineer you to "signup for their team" which is a steam account phishing page.

Game is still fun and a classic - but is clearly still in an alpha development stage. Valve trying to claim or boast that CS2 is a "competitive" shooter is completely invalid. Any "competitive" teams are phony. Faceit, ESEA and competitive game modes all filled with blatant cheaters. You could dump years of time into this game trying to "git gud" but you will never beat the script kiddies let alone be able to keep up with the constant updates to the game mechanics.

I highly encourage everyone to play this game on competitive/premiere mode and treat it as if completely casual, because it is.

Counter-Strike 2: A Masterclass in Downgrades

Ah, Counter-Strike 2. The long-awaited, heavily hyped, Source 2-powered evolution of the greatest tactical shooter of all time. And what did we get? A broken mess that makes you appreciate Counter-Strike: Global Offensive—a game we all spent years complaining about.

First, let's talk about the servers. You ever wanted to experience what it’s like to time travel? Well, now you can! Thanks to CS2’s incredible sub-tick system, every gunfight feels like you're guessing where the past version of your opponent might be, while the future version of yourself is already dead. Laggy peeks, input delay, and rubberbanding galore—it’s like Valve found the worst possible way to implement online gameplay and ran with it.

Then, we have the cheaters. Oh boy. If you ever dreamed of playing against professional aimlock enthusiasts in every second game, CS2 has you covered. The VAC system? Think of it as a museum piece—nice to look at but completely useless. Mass reporting doesn’t work, the cheaters never get banned, and somehow, they always win. It's almost impressive.

But don’t worry, CS2 did bring improvements! They gave us volumetric smokes—because that’s what everyone wanted, right? Not better matchmaking, not reliable hit registration, but dynamic, 3D smokes that look cool while you get shot through them by someone using wallhacks.

Meanwhile, Valorant exists, a game that actually runs well, has anti-cheat that does something, and doesn’t make you question if your bullets are real or just imaginary suggestions to the game engine.

Overall, Counter-Strike 2 is like getting a birthday gift from Valve where they take away your old toy and give you a newer, shinier, but completely broken version of it. 0/10 experience when playing, 10/10 experience when uninstalling.

Counter-Strike 2 was supposed to be the evolution of CS:GO. A fresh engine, better graphics, smoother gameplay. In reality? It's a downgrade in disguise. Sure, the core gunplay still slaps, the maps look cleaner, and Source 2 brings a nice visual upgrade. But once you scratch the surface, the issues hit you like a flashbang to the face.

🔸 CS:GO was just better. More features, better balance, less chaos. CS2 feels like a stripped-down, half-baked remake with prettier lighting. It lacks the polish and reliability that made CS:GO feel like home.

🔸 Cheaters. Everywhere. Despite all the “improved anti-cheat” talk from Valve, CS2 is swarming with wallhackers, spinbotters, and aim-assisted clowns. VAC is more of a meme than a system. You might get one clean match out of five – if you're lucky.

🔸 Account leaks through streams. Let that sink in – people literally lost their Steam accounts just by watching CS2 streams on Twitch. No phishing, no clicking shady links – just watching a major event. And Valve? Dead silent. No statement, no apology, no help.

🔸 Server quality is laughable. 64 tick servers in 2025 is just unacceptable. We were promised 128 tick – we got smoke gimmicks and laggy peeks. Rubberbanding, packet loss, and straight-up disconnects still happen. It’s like playing on a potato sometimes.

🔸 Missing content at launch. CS2 launched like an early-access game. No community servers, no classic modes, missing features from CS:GO that players used every day. And they’re slowly trickling back... keyword: slowly.

🔸 Matchmaking and ranks are a joke. The ranking system feels totally random. Win streak? You derank. Lose a game? Here's your promotion. No transparency, no logic – just vibes and suffering.

Final thoughts:
Counter-Strike 2 could be amazing. The gameplay foundation is still gold – it's fast, competitive, and adrenaline-pumping. But Valve has a long way to go before this game deserves to stand above CS:GO.

At the moment, I play CS2 not because it’s great, but because there's no real alternative. And deep down, I still miss CS:GO – the better, more complete version of the game I fell in love with.

Final rating: 7/10 – for what it could be, not what it currently is.

If you thought the gameplay and matchmaking issues were bad, just wait until you encounter CS2's thriving population of cheaters. This game isn’t just a playground for hackers—it’s their personal kingdom, where they run unchecked and unchallenged. Aimbots, wallhacks, spinbots—you name it, and you’ll see it in almost every match. What’s worse is that Valve doesn’t seem to care.

VAC: A Dinosaur of Anti-Cheat Systems
Valve Anti-Cheat (VAC) is the same antiquated system they’ve been parading around for years, and it’s utterly useless in Counter-Strike 2. Cheaters laugh at it as they blatantly ruin match after match. VAC bans, if they ever come, happen weeks after the damage is done—long enough for the cheater to create a new account and start the cycle all over again. It’s not just ineffective; it’s insulting.

A Cheater's Paradise
Cheaters have become so rampant in CS2 that it feels like they outnumber legitimate players in ranked matches. The sheer audacity of some of these hackers—openly mocking their opponents while flaunting their cheats—shows just how toothless Valve’s response is. Even in supposedly "high-rank" games, the presence of cheaters destroys any sense of competition or fairness.

False Promises and Empty Words
Valve promised improvements to anti-cheat for CS2, but what we got is a hollow PR statement with zero tangible results. If anything, the situation has worsened. Features like kernel-level anti-cheat, used by competitors like Riot’s Vanguard, aren’t even on the table. Instead, players are left to report cheaters manually, which feels like screaming into the void.

Impact on the Community
The cheater infestation has turned the once-loyal Counter-Strike community into a bitter, disillusioned group. Legitimate players are abandoning the game in droves, leaving only the cheaters and those masochistic enough to endure this broken experience. CS2’s potential for competitive play has been utterly destroyed by Valve’s negligence.

Counter-Strike 2 isn’t just failing to deal with cheaters—it’s actively enabling them. At this point, calling the game “unplayable” is generous. Valve’s refusal to take anti-cheat measures seriously is the ultimate betrayal to its player base. This isn’t just a problem—it’s a catastrophe.

I've long enjoyed this game however CS2 has some pretty major problems which have yet to be resolved. I've held off writing a review since I was hoping by now that it would be in a better state.

The good
I'll start with some things I like. Contrary to how a lot of people feel, I really like the graphical changes. The game is a lot better looking, but still really smooth and consistent (at least in my experience). I also greatly prefer the transparency of having a numerical value for rank as opposed to the categorical ranks of CSGO.

This game has two major issues though which I think are devastating for the competitive scene.

Firstly, elo gain and loss are almost entirely based on team loss/wins with little regard for individual performance. This means that if a GE stacks with 4 silvers continuously, all of their elo will eventually converge to be roughly the same value. I play with people that are much better than me but our elo is almost the same since we play together often. Because of how little information is utilised to adjust your rank, you'd need to solo queue for many matches to get an appropriate elo, which means you end up in an unnecessarily high number of unfair matches (either rolling the enemy team or vice versa). I think Valve tried to remedy this by bootstrapping your initial rank based on individual performance, but the initial number is often way off so this doesn't work. I get the philosophy behind this design, CS is a team based game, but this system doesn't work well in practice.


Secondly is the massive overabundance of cheaters and smurfs. The weekly drop system encourages people to make/use alt accounts, causing further problems to matchmaking since you get high rank players in <10k lobbies just trying to earn their drops. Cheating also seems to be a major issue in comparison to CSGO. It seems something has happened to our trust factor, as our match quality has very sharply plummeted and we have lost 11 premier matches (yes, ) in a row, almost all of which had blatant cheaters on the enemy team. Most accounts we play against now are throwaways. Our only hope of winning is to not 5 stack and hope we get a cheater of our own on our team, but that's not fun.

The game just isn't fun anymore since we can't find matches without throwaway cheating accounts, so I plan to take a break from CS2 and just hope that the game ends up in a better state soon so that I can continue playing.

I still play the game often and I like it, but I leave a negative review because I don't like the direction it's taken. I want CS to become better, I love playing it with my friends, I like the skins, and the community has brought me many laughs, but it feels like Valve is putting the bare minimum effort to keep the game alive and have people spend money. Here's why:

-Game released bare-bones missing many maps and game modes from CSGO

-To date, every new update makes it run worse, the latest update has issues with huge frame drops, stutters, and freezing. Frame in CSGO was consistent 400, now I'm lucky to get 160fps with half decent frame times.

-Community servers are a shambling corpse of what it was in CSGO. That side of the community is dead. All the servers are full of bots. No good AWP only servers, a few good 1v1 servers, no zombies, no deathrun or the other dozens of other fun game mode servers. That whole creative side of the community has been abandoned by Valve and given little support. Surf zoomer are eating well, at least.

-Maps are pretty BUT the amount of visual clutter only lowers frames and makes it harder to see enemies.

-Ruined factory new skins by giving them all wear. Now a factory new skin looks like a minimal wear or even field tested from CSGO. Example, Bizon Osiris. (thanks for making those skins slightly cheaper, at least)

-Player models are not accurate to hit boxes, the default CT is terrible. I've flicked to parts of the model that don't count as a hit. That is a terrible decision for a competitive game.

-No more default player models that vary depending on the map. Not a big loss, but it shows a lack of attention imo.

-The HUD keeps getting worse. It's amazing how badly they can mess this up. CSGO had a minimalist, clean, and easy to read HUD with all the important info in places that have a physical reference point irl, like the health at the bottom left. New CS2 HUD has transparency on everything, selected items don't highlight as well, I really miss the nice touch of my weapons being highlighted in the color of their rarity, mini map is harder to read, my money is bigger than my health or armor, and I don't need to know what team I am by having a big emblem in the middle of my screen. The HUD is provably and quantifiably worse than in CSGO.

-Why do we have first shot inaccuracy?? Why? Makes zero sense in this type of competitive game. Why do I need to miss my one-tap headshot when my aim is on the enemy's head? Is the game really better for having that?

-Hacker issue still not fix, and the hacks have only gotten more powerful. We are talking Rainbow Six Siege levels of absurd hacks. They can change the spread of shotguns and change the the fire rate, absurd things like that.

-Ranks and elo systems are terrible and matchmaking will put you in games that will force you to lose. I'm talking about putting you against teams with 5k more elo than anyone on your team.

-Still no overwatch system like in CSGO.

-The biggest updates we got until now is a few community maps and the ability to switch hand view model... SIX months in. You know the community is starving for content when that is considered a huge update. In CSGO that would be a normal bi-monthly update.

-Hit reg is terrible and it's probably sub-tick being terrible.

Counter-Strike 2: Not an Update, a Rebirth
At first glance, you think — oh, it's just CS:GO with ray tracing and protein shakes. Then you play it. And you realize: nope, this isn’t an update. It’s like your good old AK-47 suddenly developed a sense of smell.

CS2 is still that same adrenaline-fueled classic where one bullet can change the round, but now everything feels tangible. Source 2 didn’t just slap on better graphics — it poured a bucket of raw concrete into the game. You can feel things now: water droplets from explosions, the flicker of your teammate’s shadow around the corner, and smoke that doesn’t just exist — it lives.

Speaking of smoke — it’s no longer a wall. It’s a character. It moves, it breathes, it reacts to grenades like it’s got emotions. I wouldn’t be surprised if it starts streaming on Twitch next year.

The guns? Still the same arsenal, but every reload feels like you’re reloading your soul. The AWP doesn’t just boom anymore — it tears a hole in reality, pauses time, and gently lets you back into the match.

Servers finally hit 128-tick, and that’s like upgrading from smoke signals to quantum teleportation. Every movement is a dance. Every kill? Poetry. The feel is tighter, snappier, and your muscle memory comes back like a loyal dog that never really left.

It’s not perfect — hitboxes sometimes act like confused teenagers, and the UI is a bit extra. Matchmaking still throws you in with people who think the bomb site is a Spotify playlist. But that’s fine. CS2 is a foundation, not a fad. It's here to evolve.

The Verdict:
CS2 isn’t the second chapter. It’s a second life. For the aim gods and the eco warriors. For the smurfs, the noobs, the spray control philosophers. It’s not just a game — it’s the art of control, the sound of chaos, and the silence before the last shot.

The suffering I’ve endured from playing Counter-Strike is a complex blend of mental, emotional, and even physical pain. It begins with the countless hours spent grinding in competitive matches, where every loss feels like a personal failure, a reflection of my inadequacies. I’ve experienced the gut-wrenching agony of getting matched with teammates who seem to have no regard for teamwork or strategy, leaving me to carry the game on my own shoulders. The weight of that responsibility crushes my spirit, especially when I still lose despite my best efforts. Every missed shot feels like a betrayal of my own hands, a reminder that no matter how many hours I pour into improving my aim or game sense, there are still moments where I am utterly powerless. The suffocating tension of a 1v1 clutch situation is something I’ve felt in my bones, the pressure building as the seconds tick away, my palms sweating, heart racing, only to die to some sniper crouching in a corner, completely erasing any hope of victory.

The toxicity of the community adds another layer to the pain. It’s not just the personal failures; it’s the verbal abuse that follows. No matter how well I play, there’s always that one teammate who’s quick to hurl insults, to tear down whatever little confidence I’ve built. The constant barrage of blame, the accusations that I’m throwing the game or that I’m a noob, gnaws away at my self-esteem. Every match feels like a battlefield, not just against the enemy team but against my own squad, fighting to maintain my mental stability while being bombarded by insults, racial slurs, and unnecessary aggression. Then there’s the pain of seeing a perfectly executed strategy fall apart due to one small mistake, whether it's a missed flashbang or an ill-timed push. The frustration builds with every game, the crushing realization that even though I’ve spent hundreds, maybe thousands, of hours in the game, I’m still not where I want to be skill-wise.

Physically, the game has taken its toll as well. My back and wrists ache from sitting in the same position for hours, hunched over, eyes glued to the screen, fingers moving in a precise, rapid-fire rhythm. The late nights have robbed me of sleep, leaving me exhausted, but I can’t stop playing because I’m chasing that one good game, that fleeting moment of victory that keeps me coming back, even though deep down I know that satisfaction will never outweigh the frustration. Counter-Strike has become a cycle of suffering, where each win is quickly overshadowed by a string of losses, and every moment of joy is drowned out by the ever-present, gnawing feeling of defeat.

The graphics are nice, I guess. I mean, who doesn't love watching their opponents' avatars do the "I just got killed by a 12-year-old with a sensitivity of 400" dance? It's like Valve hired a team of expert animators to craft the perfect "I'm about to rage-quit" facial expressions.

And don't even get me started on the community. I'm pretty sure the only thing more toxic than the game's chat is the water in a Chernobyl cooling tower. It's like everyone's competing in some sort of twisted, masochistic game of "Who Can Be the Most Creative with Their Insults." I've seen more civil discourse at a Kanye West concert.

In conclusion, CS2 is a game that will simultaneously make you want to pull your hair out and scream "ONE MORE ROUND!" until the wee hours of the morning. It's like a bad relationship – you know it's not good for you, but you just can't help yourself.

My journey with Counter-Strike began back in the days of version 1.5. I fell in love with the pure competitive spirit hidden within those simple pixels. Every round, every clutch moment, every aim duel stirred a unique excitement inside me. CS wasn’t just a game to me—it was a passion, a love, a way of life. I spent days grinding, nights without sleep, dreaming of becoming a pro. I wanted to wear a team jersey, compete in tournaments, and hear my name echo in the arena. But talent alone wasn’t enough, and the circumstances at the time didn’t work in my favor. Still, the fire in me never faded.

As the years passed, versions evolved—CS 1.6, Source, Global Offensive—and I followed them all. I was always there, part of it. But eventually, the unfairness within the game—especially the cheaters—began to drain my love for it. Every match started to feel pointless. "Was there a cheater again?" became my routine question.

At some point, I gave in. I betrayed the purity of my passion. I told myself, “If everyone else is doing it, why not me?” I deeply regret it to this day. I ended up getting my most valuable accounts—full of years of effort and memories—banned. The shame of those actions still lingers within me like a scar.

But even through all that, I never stopped loving CS. Because CS was a reflection of me. The sounds of gunfire, the ticking bombs, the mid-round calls—they became the soundtrack of my youth. The discipline, reaction speed, and mental strength I developed thanks to CS helped me far beyond the screen.

Now, CS2 is here. With a brand-new engine, more realistic physics, advanced lighting and shadows—it offers a fresh, immersive experience. But to be honest, it still needs work. Optimization issues, matchmaking problems, and bugs still affect gameplay. However, that doesn't mean it can’t improve. CS has always been a game that evolves and matures over time.

Counter-Strike is my childhood love. My first passion. My first real thrill. And that kind of love never dies. It only transforms. CS will live on forever—because it lives in us. In the players who gave their hearts to it.

CS never dies. It simply gets reborn.

Maps like Dust2 and Mirage have been beautifully reimagined, with enhanced textures and dynamic lighting that make them feel fresh yet familiar. The game’s visual fidelity truly stands out, especially when compared to its predecessor.

- Smooth Performance: Despite the graphical improvements, the game runs surprisingly well on my setup. I haven’t experienced any significant performance drops, and the frame rates remain consistent even during intense firefights. Valve seems to have done a good job optimizing the game for a wide range of hardware.
